SP.P: Yes, sir; we shall have three times, I reckon, to stop in the snow; about five hours at a spill.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: In the snow!

SP.SPEAKER: Guil.
SP.P: Yes, sir; but then your love will keep you warm.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: To be sure I would undergo a little in con∣sideration of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Guil.
SP.P: And then I hope you are pretty well as to courage, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: How do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Guil.
SP.P: Why, sir; they say there's a woundy sight of robbers that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: Robbers! hang it, that's unlucky.—Well, but I hope they are none of those damn'd banditti rascals who murder people?

SP.SPEAKER: Guil.
SP.P: Always.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: An't you afraid, then, for yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Guil.
SP.P: O Sir, they never touch the guide.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: Well, I must consult the Marquis about it. At all events get ready.—Where shall I find you?

SP.SPEAKER: Guil.
SP.P: Oh, at uncle's.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: You know the way?

SP.SPEAKER: Guil.
SP.P: Yes, yes; every inch of it.—Let me see.

LG.L: Off we go from Break-neck-steep,
Softly, softly, jades, so! so!
'Till we see the mountains peep,
Cover'd with huge heaps of snow.
But small matters travellers never must mind;
We laugh at each stumble, and sing at each trip;
For you, sir, d'ye see,
You've to cheer up your spirits, a kind coming fair,
Who, the more we're in danger, the more will be kind.
And then, as for me,
I've a drop in my pocket to keep out the air,
And I'm always reviv'd at the smack of the whip.
By-and-by to Cripple-hill,
Tired and jaded we arrive;
Where, for some hours, we stand still,
The worn-out cattle scarce alive.
But small matters, &c.
'See the carriage one side hang,
'And now upon its end, and now,
'Apart the breaking traces bang,
'And souse we tumble in a slough.
'But small matters, &c.'
Next, to Cut-throat dale we reach;
Where, from behind some lonely bush,
With blunderbuss, and pistols each,
A dozen lurking villains rush.
But small matters, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: I must throw none of these objections in her way:—here she is. Well, my love, you are come in good time: we shall have a carriage directly, and then upon the wings of love.—

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: Ay, all that's very well, if I could believe you'd love me for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: How can you think otherwise? who would not have done as much as I have, for the tender, gentle, beautiful Shepherdess of the Alps? your distress bespoke my pity; pity softened into love, and love commanded me to throw myself and my fortune at your feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: Yes, but ours has been but a short acquain∣tance; and how do I know but you wants to inveigle me away for some wicked purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: My dear, I would not harbour such a thought for the world: my intention is to take you directly to Turin, there to bespeak you clothes, jewels, every thing proper for your intended situation; and when my twelvemonth and a day expires, to marry you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: Twelvemonth and a day!

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: Yes, my dear; you know it would not be decent before.

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: I can tell you, Sir, I won't wait so long as that:—to love you so dearly as I do, indeed, and not be married 'till then!

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: But, my life, what can I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: Why? marry me before you go.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: Consider, love:—besides there's no such thing as getting a priest.

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: O Lord! our curate will do the job, and thank you into the bargain, if you'll give him a good fee; and then, as I am to be a lady, you know, I can't see why you may not bring me acquainted with the gentlefolks, and then we may all go away together.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: That's true; but if they find I have made such a sudden resolution—

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: They may laugh at you, perhaps you think; Oh, sir, if you are ashamed of your choice, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: No, my life, it is not that.

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: I can tell you, sir, I would not turn my back for virtue and honesty to any one; and then as to beauty—

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: Venus was never half so handsome.

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: I don't know she, but I am sure I am very well to pass.

SP.SPEAKER: Count,
SP.P: Zounds! I shall lose her. My love, you are every thing to me, and your will shall be obey'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: Ay, that's saying something; but I think you had better make me acquainted with the gentlefolks first, and then you may get one of your friends to stand father.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: A good thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: And another thing;—you don't think of mar∣rying me in that dismal suit of clothes, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: My dear, I have no other with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: Oh, I dare say the gentleman will lend you some.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: Well, but.—

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: Ah, there! You are at your buts again.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: Well, well, I'll make no objections; every thing shall be as you desire it: I'll go and find the Marquis directly.—Adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Jean.
SP.P: Oh dear! how I shall laugh to see him in his finery.

LG.L: Ah men what silly things you are,
To woman thus to humble;
Who, fowler like, but spreads her snare,
Or at her timid game,
Takes aim,
Pop, pop, and down you tumble.
She marks you down, fly where you will,
O'er clover, grass, or stubble;
Can wing you, feather you, or kill,
Just as she takes the trouble.
Ah men, &c.
Then fly not from us, 'tis in vain,
We know the art of setting,
As well as shooting, and can train
The shyest man our not in.
Ah men, &c.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IX.
DIV2.STAGE: The Tomb seen in another point of View.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: Three hours have I waited here in anxious expectation, contemplating every one of those objects that have so often been silent witnesses of her grief:—all nature seems to respect it—and where-e'er she comes, like gloomy mists at the approach of day, all other objects shrink back, and behold her approach with silent admiration—what can it be?

LG.L: Bright gems that twinkle from afar,
Planets, and every lesser star,
Who darting each a downward ray,
Console us for the loss of day.
Begone, even Venus who so bright,
Reflects her visions pure and white;
Instant begone, and quit the skies,
For lo! the moon begins to rise.
Ye pretty warblers of the grove,
Who chant such artless tales of love;
The throstle, gurgling in his throat;
The linnet, with his silver note.
The soaring lark, the whistling thrush,
The merry blackbird, goldfinch, hush,
Fly, vanish, disappear, take wing,
The nightingale begins to sing.

SP.P: But she is here, and all at once the blood for∣sakes my very heart; how I tremble to approach her!

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: I have made you wait; but I'll hasten to re∣compense your patience; you know upon what con∣ditions you are to hear my story; let us speak to one another then without disguise. I'll begin, and let my confidence encourage your's; listen—my unhappi∣ness will be a lesson for you—Shepherd, behold this tomb.

LG.L: Here sleeps in peace, beneath this rustic vase,
The tenderest lover a husband could prove;
Of all his distress, alas, I am the cause;
So much I ador'd him, heaven envied my love.
The sighs I respire ev'ry morn I arise,
The misery I cherish, the grief, and the pain;
The thousand of tears that fall from my eyes,
Are all the sad comforts, for me, that remain.
When, his colours display'd, honour call'd him to arms;
By tender perswasions I kept him away;
His glory forgetting for those fatal charms;
And, to punish me, he is depriv'd of the day.
Since when to his memory I've rais'd this sad tomb,
Where to join him, alas! I shall shortly descend;
Where sorrow, nor pain, nor affliction can come,
And where both my love, and my crime shall have end.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Now tell me of what parents you are born, and what reduced you to the state of shepherd?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: Cease to question me, 'twould afflict you to know an ill you cannot cure. You are unhappy, but I am more so; and such is the nature of my distress, that an eternal silence must lock it up in my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Alas! how can I without knowing who you are, and what are your troubles, any longer place a confidence in you? the mystery you make raises a cloud between us.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: Don't be offended at my silence! 'tis ter∣rible to be condemned to it. The assiduous companion of all your steps, I'll sweeten your labour; I'll partake your cares, and you shall never repent of having reposed your miseries in a heart, alas! but too sensible.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: No, it cannot be; I exact from you the most sincere confession, and I think I merit it; I have spoken to you without mystery, and you ought to imi∣tate me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: Alas! let me finish my deplorable life, with∣out leaving you to reproach yourself with having shortened it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Sill more and more mysterious.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: What would you have me say then?—I am—

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Speak!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: Bellemine! the son of those travellers you so penetrated with respect and admiration.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: And you have left your unhappy family in tears?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: Their report of your virtues and your charms, inspired me with the fatal design to come and see you thus disguised; you therefore know the cause of my error.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: O fly and console—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: Spare me unuseful counsels and reproaches; my resolution is as fixed, as unalterable as your's; I see all the repugnance you have to make me unhappy; I see your heart is with him who reposes in that tomb; I see that nothing can detach you from it; your duty is never to love me, and my fate for ever to adore you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: [Looking after him] Poor Bellemine!

SP.SPEAKER: Abbé.
SP.P: Here she is. Come, ma'am, you seem a lady fond of adventures, and therefore I hope you'll not make much resistance; come let me gently force you to be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: What do you mean, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Abbé.
SP.P: [Taking hold of her.] My dear, I can't tk, I shall have time enough to obtain my pardon: here my honest fellows, assist me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Oh, [shrieks] Heaven! what would you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: How's this? Adelaide in distress!—hold off, you ruffians! [They turn upon him, Adelaide runs off] Nay, I regard not your numbers. What do I see, the Abbé dela Mouche!

SP.SPEAKER: Abbé.
SP.P: Young Bellemine!

STAGE.HI: Abbé, Young Bellemine, Marquis, Marchioness Adelaide, Blaise, Renette.

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: [Speaking as he comes on] Where are they? where are they? never fear my boy, the dog has courage enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: My father! gods!

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: [Shewing Young Bellemine to his mother] Ma∣dam, I have fulfilled my promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: So, Mr. Abbé you are there! did not I tell you, you had better be quiet? you little thought what a terrier I had to set after your heels.

SP.SPEAKER: Abbé.
SP.P: I little expected, indeed, the pleasure of see∣ing Mr. Bellemine.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: Nor that you should be chastized, I suppose, for the outrage you have meditated against decency, and the laws.

SP.SPEAKER: Abbé.
SP.P: Sir, there's no talking here; you'll find me at Turin.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: I will find you at Turin, Sir; in the mean time begone! and thank this company that I part with you upon such easy terms.

SP.SPEAKER: Abbé.
SP.P: Here, la Pierre; at Turin, Mr. Bellemine, I shall expect the pleasure of seeing you, Sir; in the mean time, I am this company's most obedient slave.

LG.L: Thus do we find the tender flower
Shrink from the sun whose warmth it loves.

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: So, you young dog, I have had a pretty race after you, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: Pardon me, Sir, nor make me more miserable than I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: Oh, my dear child, why would you be so cruel to leave me in such despair?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: I feel, madam, how much these reproaches are my due; but by the ills I endure, love is reveng∣ed of nature, and your son is lost.

SP.SPEAKER: March.
SP.P: How! my child?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: I have done every thing, quitted every thing for her; answer me, could I love any thing more beau∣tiful? but I adore in vain; a young and faithful widow, she weeps a husband buried in that tomb.

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: 'Tis for that then, so young and handsome, she has quitted the world.

SP.SPEAKER: March.
SP.P: The name of your husband, my dear child?

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Dorestan.

SP.SPEAKER: March.
SP.P: And your's?

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Seville.

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: Why, I know both the names as well, as my own. Did not I say my boy knew what he was about? why, you dog, she is descended from one of the best families in France.

SP.SPEAKER: March.
SP.P: Indeed, child, her heart was worthy of you; but the love you have conceived for her, is a flame that must be extinguished.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: If I must quit Adelaide, I shall soon after quit the light; I feel too well, that the same instant will decide my life and my love.

SP.SPEAKER: March.
SP.P: You see, child, his extreme unhappiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Ah! how miserable I am!

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: Come, come, why should we stay here to afflict her? I did not believe it a matter so serious as this: we won't ask you, Adelaide, to accompany us.

SP.SPEAKER: March.
SP.P: I wish to heaven she would.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Alas! madam, how can I?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: Adieu, all that I love. [Tenderly.]

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Adieu, Bellemine. [Hesitating.]

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: Oh, what an effort! no, I feel I shall sink under it; let me then upon this tomb.
SP.STAGE: [He is going to throw himself upon the tomb, and the Marquis catches him in his arms.]

SP.SPEAKER: March.
SP.P: Alas! Adelaide, your heart is without pity, and for a family too who have so much friendship for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Dear madam, what would you have me do?

SP.SPEAKER: March.
SP.P: I would have you go with us: I ask not for a return of my child's love, your pity will suffice, and that I implore; without that, you'll cause his death; and alas, mine soon afterwards!

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Dear madam.

SP.SPEAKER: March.
SP.P: Save my child! make this effort; a mother upon her knees asks his life.

SP.SPEAKER: Blaise.
SP.P: Indeed, my dear child, you make madam too unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ren.
SP.P: Pray, pray, consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: Nay, nay, Adelaide, I must put in a word now: how can you deny us? besides your adventure will be known every where; nay, have you not al∣ready been exposed to violence? though, thanks to my boy, you were rescued from it: for his sake then, for your own,—

SP.SPEAKER: Blaise.
SP.P: For all our sakes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.STAGE: [She looks separately at them all, as they suppli∣cate her, and at last goes up to the tomb.]
SP.P: Oh Dorestan, thy heart was noble and generous; and if thou canst read in the bottom of my mind, thou wilt not com∣plain of so holy a duty.—Rise, Bellemine!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: What voice was that! [starting up.]

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: What voice! why the voice of thy Ade∣laide, who consents to go with us to Turin; oh! you young dog, you have got the use of your limbs now, I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: Oh, my Adelaide!

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: What the devil have we here?

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XV.
DIV2.STAGE: Marquis, Marchioness, Y. B. Adelaide, Blaise, Renette, Count, Jeannotte. [The Count dressed out.]

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: Give me joy! my friends, give me joy!

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: Ah, the Count!

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: Yes, not the whining, crying Count; but the laughing, happy Count; zounds! I can't help thinking what an ass I have been; to be sure, 'tis a sudden change; but who'll blame me when they know what a temptation was thrown in my way; the lovely, solitary shepherdess of the Alps!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. B.
SP.P: How's this!

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE the last.
DIV2.STAGE: To them, Guillot dressed for his Journey.

SP.SPEAKER: Guil.
SP.P: I crave pardon; oh! Sir, you are there; well, every thing is ready, the cattle are too— [seeing Jeannotte toying with the Count.] Heyday! Jeannotte, what is all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: Jeannotte! what does the fellow mean by Jeannotte? Sir, this is the lovely Adelaide; the Shepherdess of the Alps.

SP.SPEAKER: Guil.
SP.P: Oh lord! I know a little better than that too; 'tis our Jeannotte, I tell you; and, to say the truth, I don't understand her toying about along of you, when she is to be married this morning to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: What is all this, Marquis?

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: 'Tis very true, Count, I assure you; yonder's Adelaide with my son.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: And have I then swerved from my duty; dressed myself up like a mountebank? this was your contrivance then, Marquis.

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: It was indeed, Count.

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: And pray, Sir, why?

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: I'll tell you why: from an inveterate aver∣sion I have to every sort of hypocrisy; come, come, I'll settle all your future situations: you and Jeannotte shall enjoy your farm; which my son shall restore you again; Blaise and Renette shall go with us; and, as they have lived like Baucis and Philemon, so shall they die; for I'll change their cottage into a palace—As for you, Count—

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.P: I am a wretch, a puppy; I feel it, and will never shew my face again; I'll get into my weeds, and never more be comforted.

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P:
An excellent resolution! and there never was so fine an opportunity; and dam'me, if I was you, I'd stay here in these wild mountains; let my hair and my claws grew, and vegetage, like Nebuchad∣nezzar;
and now, my amiable daughter, we'll restore you to the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Alas, sir! how shall I bear its reproaches?

SP.SPEAKER: Marq.
SP.P: What reproaches! let it have been witness to our united solicitations, let it have seen the noble conflict in your mind, and then, could the severest censurer have denied, that the Shepherdess of the Alps was amiable, even in her infidelity?

LG.L: Each kind auspicious power,
If goodness is your care,
Exhaustless blessings shower
Upon this tender pair.
Ah me! what joy! no never
Will I again repine;
My Adelaide is, for ever,
Ye powers! for ever mine;
Ne'er will I let her languish,
But every care employ
To turn, each tear of anguish
Into a smile of joy.
Thus trying to deserve her all I may,
I'll give the talking world right cause to say—
Each kind auspicious power,
If goodness is your care,
Exhaustless blessings shower
Upon this tender pair.
Adieu, ye woods, ye fountains,
Adieu, my pretty sheep,
Who oft' have left the mountains,
And gaz'd to see me weep.
And ah! may'st thou acquit me,
Belov'd and honour'd shade,
And own, as did befit me,
I every duty paid.
Not but a tear, thy tribute, oft' I'll pay,
That all the world may still have cause to say—
Each kind auspicious power,
If goodness is your care,
Exhaustless blessings shower
Upon this tender pair.
Now critics, your election
We wait with anxious care;
Oh! give your kind protection
To this, else, wretched pair!
To comfort her's your duty;
For should you give her pain,
'Twill be the first time beauty
Has pleaded here in vain.
No, rather send us, smiling, all away;
And, joining chorus, clap your hands and say—
Each kind auspicious power,
If goodness is your care,
Exhaustless blessings shower
Upon this tender pair.
